text: Hi guys, I've been trying things out with betfairlightweight for a while. I can get prices, place bets, etc but getting prices/lines for Asian Handicap markets has stumped me. I've been searching round for guidance and found <https://support.developer.betfair.com/hc/en-us/articles/360016170431-How-do-I-place-bets-on-handicap-markets-|this> but I'm struggling to implement it with BFLW. Does anyone know of any examples or can someone point me in the right direction? Thanks

attachments.fallback: Betfair Developer Program: How do I place bets on handicap markets?
attachments.text: For specific markets/bettingTypes (e.g. marketTypes ASIAN_HANDICAP_DOUBLE_LINE, ASIAN_HANDICAP_SINGLE_LINE) you need to include the relevant selections handicap value in the placeOrders request alo...
attachments.title: How do I place bets on handicap markets?

elements.text: Hi guys, I've been trying things out with betfairlightweight for a while. I can get prices, place bets, etc but getting prices/lines for Asian Handicap markets has stumped me. I've been searching round for guidance and found
this
but I'm struggling to implement it with BFLW. Does anyone know of any examples or can someone point me in the right direction? Thanks

text: What have you tried?

elements.text: What have you tried?

text: Hi Mo, I can filter events to find matches with AH markets using `matFilter = betfairlightweight.filters.market_filter(event_type_ids=[1], market_start_time={'to': (datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(hours=1)).strftime("%Y-%m-%dT%TZ")}, market_betting_types=["ASIAN_HANDICAP_DOUBLE_LINE"])` but then I'm not able to get the prices/lines for a specific event.

matFilter = betfairlightweight.filters.market_filter(event_type_ids=[1], market_start_time={'to': (datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(hours=1)).strftime("%Y-%m-%dT%TZ")}, market_betting_types=["ASIAN_HANDICAP_DOUBLE_LINE"])
but then I'm not able to get the prices/lines for a specific event.

I select the event ID then filter using
`markCatFilt = betfairlightweight.filters.market_filter(event_ids=[event_id])`
`markCats = trading.betting.list_market_catalogue(filter=markCatFilt, max_results='100', sort='FIRST_TO_START')`
And this is where I get stuck

markCats = trading.betting.list_market_catalogue(filter=markCatFilt, max_results='100', sort='FIRST_TO_START')
And this is where I get stuck

text: Stuck how? How is this different to how you get prices when you say "I can get prices"

elements.text: Stuck how? How is this different to how you get prices when you say "I can get prices"

text: Morning. Are there any issues running simulation against a directory of files, where that directory is the one being used currently to record markets too? Thanks

elements.text: Morning. Are there any issues running simulation against a directory of files, where that directory is the one being used currently to record markets too? Thanks

text: "should" be ok since simulation would be using zipped files and recording raw files. But ! - if you are continually scanning the directory for new files you might hit a sharing problem at the instant the recorder transforms the raw file to a zipped one depending on how file attributes/properties are being handled. One scan to find all zipped files and then backtest should be ok though imho.

elements.text: "should" be ok since simulation would be using zipped files and recording raw files. But ! - if you are continually scanning the directory for new files you might hit a sharing problem at the instant the recorder transforms the raw file to a zipped one depending on how file attributes/properties are being handled. One scan to find all zipped files and then backtest should be ok though imho.

text:
Thanks Foxwood. Ive been dragging the files down from the virtual server for backtesting locally but I may as well just add some extra disk space on AWS. its not that expensive in the grand scheme of things.
Thanks for the reply :+1:

text: Hi, I'm trying to get the match_date in Flumine when looking at previously matched bets, but it's returning an empty list to me even though runner.traded_volume does return a dictionary of values. I'm looking to get the match date for some of the trades, does anyone know how I can subscribe to this data?

Do you fuzzy search events (eg "Liverpool v Crystal Palace") or individual teams? It's data-dependent I know, but do you do any pre-processing?

text: Is there a good way to get current exposure on a runner without going through the blotter? similar to `runner_context.trade_count` but for exposure?

elements.text: Is there a good way to get current exposure on a runner without going through the blotter? similar to
runner_context.trade_count
but for exposure?

text:
Maybe this?

`lookup = (market.market_id, r.selection_id, r.handicap)
exposure = market.blotter.selection_exposure(self, lookup)`
Edit: sorry, you said _without_ using the blotter, so no other way that I'm aware of. Any reason why you want to avoid the blotter?

elements.text: Maybe this?
lookup = (market.market_id, r.selection_id, r.handicap)
exposure = market.blotter.selection_exposure(self, lookup)
Edit: sorry, you said
without
using the blotter, so no other way that I'm aware of. Any reason why you want to avoid the blotter?
